1.text: Begin looking for bagworms during the winter or early spring.

2.text: Sweep and rake under trees regularly to get rid of fallen egg sacks.

3.text: Notice areas of dead pine needles or branches.

4.text: Observe new places the bagworms may live.

5.text: Fill a plastic bucket with a mixture of warm water and dish soap.

6.text: Put on garden gloves and bring a small pair of clippers to aid you in removing the bagworms entirely.

7.text: Lift branches, clip off bagworm egg sacks and drop them into the bucket of soapy water.

8.text: Dump the soaked bagworms into a sealed plastic sack and throw them in your dumpster.

9.text: Repeat this procedure every fall, winter and early spring to reduce bagworm populations before the eggs hatch.

10.text: Plan to treat bagworms with insecticide in May.

11.text: Look for a small, worm-like head poking out of the top of the sack.

12.text: Purchase an insecticide such as Dipel or Thuricide.

13.text: Put the insecticide in a sprayer.

14.text: Spray insecticide in late May, June and early July.
